title: Gaussian Integer Factorization
description: Calculate the prime factorization of Gaussian integers, a special type of complex numbers.

error.notGaussian: The input is not a Gaussian integer.

about.title: What are Gaussian Integers?
about.description: Gaussian integers are complex numbers whose real and imaginary parts are both integers.
about.imaginaryUnit: where i is the imaginary unit (i² = -1).

factorization.title: About Prime Factorization
factorization.difference: Prime factorization in Gaussian integers differs from that in rational integers. For example:
factorization.example1: 2 is prime in rational integers but factors as (1+i)(1-i) in Gaussian integers.
factorization.example2: A prime p ≡ 1 (mod 4) can be factored into two Gaussian primes.
factorization.example3: A prime p ≡ 3 (mod 4) remains prime in Gaussian integers.

algorithm.title: Implementation Details
algorithm.description: This application uses the following algorithm:
algorithm.step1: 1. Treat the input integer n as a Gaussian integer.
algorithm.step3: 3. Factor N(n) as a rational integer.
algorithm.step4: 4. Find corresponding Gaussian primes for each prime factor.
algorithm.step5: 5. Finally, multiply all factors to get the result.
